netsquid.qubits.dmutil

Utility functions for manipulating density matrices.

These functions are independent from the density matrix quantum state formalism.

Examples

Several of the API functions provide example code snippets. These snippets should run unedited if you set up a Python interpreter with the following imports:

>>> import numpy as np
>>> from netsquid.qubits.dmutil import *
>>> from netsquid.qubits.ketstates import s0, s1, h0, h1, b00
netsquid.qubits.dmutil.reorder_dm(ndarray rho, list qubit_indices) → ndarray

Reorder a density matrix based on a specified qubit index ordering.

Parameters:

  • rho (numpy.array) – Density matrix.

  • qubit_indices (list of int) – New index location for each qubit index.

Returns:

A reordered density matrix.

Return type:

numpy.array

Raises:

ValueError – If qubit_indices list is not complete.

Example

>>> psi = np.kron(s0, h1)
>>> rho = psi * psi.conj().transpose()
>>> print(rho)
[[ 0.5+0.j -0.5-0.j  0. +0.j  0. -0.j]
 [-0.5+0.j  0.5+0.j  0. +0.j  0. +0.j]
 [ 0. +0.j  0. -0.j  0. +0.j  0. -0.j]
 [ 0. +0.j  0. +0.j  0. +0.j  0. +0.j]]
>>> reorder_dm(rho, [1, 0])
array([[ 0.5+0.j,  0. +0.j, -0.5-0.j,  0. -0.j],
       [ 0. +0.j,  0. +0.j,  0. -0.j,  0. -0.j],
       [-0.5+0.j,  0. +0.j,  0.5+0.j,  0. +0.j],
       [ 0. +0.j,  0. +0.j,  0. +0.j,  0. +0.j]])
netsquid.qubits.dmutil.partialtrace(ndarray rho, list qubit_indices) → ndarray

Trace out qubit(s) from a density matrix.

Parameters:

  • rho (numpy.array) – Input density matrix.

  • qubit_indices (list of int) – Indices of qubit(s) in density matrix to trace out.

Returns:

Density matrix with qubit(s) traced out.

Return type:

numpy.array

Example

>>> psi = np.kron(b00, h1)
>>> rho = psi * psi.conj().transpose()
>>> partialtrace(rho, [1])
array([[ 0.25+0.j, -0.25+0.j,  0.  +0.j,  0.  +0.j],
       [-0.25+0.j,  0.25+0.j,  0.  +0.j,  0.  +0.j],
       [ 0.  +0.j,  0.  +0.j,  0.25+0.j, -0.25+0.j],
       [ 0.  +0.j,  0.  +0.j, -0.25+0.j,  0.25+0.j]])
netsquid.qubits.dmutil.reduced_dm(ndarray rho, list qubit_indices) → ndarray

Returns the reduced density matrix for the given qubit(s).

This is the result of tracing the qubit indices not be kept and reordering the result.

Parameters:

  • rho (numpy.array) – Input density matrix.

  • qubit_indices (list of int) – Indices of qubit(s) in density matrix to keep. The rest will be traced out. The order of the indices will define the vector space for the reduced state.

Returns:

Density matrix representing the reduced density matrix.

Return type:

numpy.array

netsquid.qubits.dmutil.dm_fidelity(rho_A, rho_B, squared=False, dm_check=True)

Computes the fidelity between two density matrices.

Parameters:

  • rho_A (numpy.array) – Input density matrix.

  • rho_B (numpy.array) – Input density matrix.

  • squared (bool, optional) – If True the squared fidelity is returned.

  • dm_check (bool, optional) – If True check if the input density matrices are valid.

Returns:

The fidelity of the density matrices

Return type:

float

netsquid.qubits.dmutil.is_valid_dm(rho)

Check if a matrix is a valid density matrix.

Checks that the matrix is positive with a trace of one.

Parameters:

rho (numpy.array) – Matrix for which to check if it is a valid density matrix.

Returns:

Whether input matrix is a valid density matrix.

Return type:

bool

netsquid.qubits.dmutil.calc_amplitude_dampen_ops(double gamma, double prob, bool cache, int cache_precision)

Calculate the kraus operators and weights for the amplitude dampen operation.

Parameters:

  • gamma (float) – Damping parameter.

  • prob (float) – Propability (p) defining the stationary state (see below)

  • cache (bool) – Wheter to use caching to speed up computation for identical gamma and prob parameters (up to cache_precision).

  • cache_precision (int) – Decimal place precision to round caching lookkup parameter(s) to. If set to -1, then no rounding is performed.
